introduction.p: Previously, we defined a linear transformation between \mathbb{R}^n and \mathbb{R}^m. More generally, we can define it for two arbitrary vector spaces V, W.

subsection.title: Linear Transformations
subsection.p: Let V, W be vector spaces.

definition.p: A transformation T from V to W is a rule that assigns to each vector \vec{x} \in V a unique vector T(\vec{x}) in W.

subsection.definition:
A transformation T from V to W is linear if,
T(\vec{x} + \vec{y}) = T(\vec{x}) + T(\vec{y}) for all \vec{x}, \vec{y} \in V.
T(c \vec{x}) = c T(\vec{x}) for all c \in \mathbb{R}, \vec{x} \in V.

subsection.title: Kernel and Range
subsection.p: Then, we can define analogous concepts for the column space and null space, for linear transformations. Let T be a linear transformation from V to W.
subsection.definition:
The kernel of T, \Ker{T}, is the set of all \vec{v} \in V such that T(\vec{v}) = \vec{0} (where \vec{0} is the zero vector in W). In other words,
\boxed{\Ker{T} = \set{\vec{v} \in V: T(\vec{v}) = \vec{0}}}

The image of T, \Ima{T}, is the set of all vectors in W that T maps to. In other words,
\boxed{\Ima{T} = \set{T(\vec{v}): \vec{v} \in V}
subsection.p: If T has a matrix representation, say T(\vec{x}) = A\vec{x} for a matrix A, then the kernel and image of T are precisely the null space and column space of A, respectively.
